title: R497 road (Ireland)
text:
The R497 road is a <a href="Regional%20road%20%28Ireland%29">regional road</a> in <a href="Republic%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a> which runs north-south from <a href="Nenagh">Nenagh</a>, <a href="County%20Tipperary">County Tipperary</a> to the <a href="N24%20road%20%28Ireland%29">N24</a> in <a href="Tipperary%20%28town%29">Tipperary</a> Town.
The entire route is in County Tipperary and is long. Part of the road is known as the Anglesey Road, named after the <a href="Marquis%20of%20Anglesey">Marquis of Anglesey</a> who gave orders to have it built.
Just north of the village of <a href="Hollyford%2C%20County%20Tipperary">Hollyford</a> the road passes through Anglesey Road special area of conservation (site reference code 002125), a small site containing a variety of habitats and species found in unimproved upland grassland within the steep valley of the Multeen, a tributary of the River Suir. The main threat to the site is agricultural improvement and afforestation.
